coredata.dc:title: How far can electrons be transferred?
coredata.dc:creator: Shimada, K.
Szwarc, M.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The intramolecular electron transfer between two naphthyl moieties (N) of trans-1,4-bis-(α-naphthyl-methyl)-cyclohexane in HMPA was studied over a range of temperatures
. Although the inspection of the model indicates a separation by 9 Å between the naphthyl groups the frequency of transfer is 0.9 × 107 s−1 at 15°C.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volurne28,n mber4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEflERS 15 October 1974 HOW.FAR CAN LECTRONS BE TRANSFERRED? K. SHIMADA and M. SZWARC Department of Ozemistry, SULlY College of Environmeetal Science and Forestry, Syracuse,New York 13210, USA Received 22 April 1974 Revised manuscript received 21 June 1974 The intramolecular electron transfer between two naphthy~ moieties N) of rranr-1,4 bis-(a-nap]ithyl-methyi) cycloh xane in HMPA was studied over a range of temperatures NCH2 c-CsHso CHaN c~N.CH2 c-C6H10 CH2N. Although the inspection of the model indicates a separation by 9 A between the naphthyl groups the frequency of transfer is 0.9 X JO1 s~ at 15 C. Following the pioneering work of Weissnian and his associates [1 3], many investigators have studied the kinetics of electron transfer between radical an- ions and their parent molecules. The rate constant of the transfer is determined from the broadening of the ESR hyperfine lines in the slow exchange [l 3] or from the degree of narrowing of the collapsed spec- trum in the fast exchange [4]. A procedure, appli- cable at any rate of exchange, is also available [5,6]. - For radical ions present as ion pairs, the electron transfer has to proceed simultaneously with the trans- fer of an associated counterion, and this hinders the reaction. However, exchange involving free ions ap- pear to be diffusion controlled [3,7], i.e., in.e-ach en- counter its probability is 0.5. The above statement raises the question of what constitutes an encounter. The probability of transfer is a function of their mutual orientation and of the distance, r, separating the partners. We may ask, therefore, at what distance, r1, the transfer is still measurable. Studies of intramolecular electron ex- change may provide the required information. The problem of intramolecular electron transfer has been discussed by several workers. McConnell [8] treated the transfer between two phenyl groups link- ~edbya chain of n CH2 units on the assumption that 540 the interaction between the aromatic systems is facil- itated through an overlap of their ir orbitais with the antibonding orbitais of the aliphatic hydrocarbon chain. Such a process is classified as a transfer through a chain. McConnell s calculations led to the conclu- sion that the transfer is fast for n = I and 2 its fre- quency being greater than M (in cps), where a denotes the couplin3 constants characterizing the pertinent ESR spectra. According to his calculations insertion of each additional CH2 unit should reduce the rate of exchange by a factor of 10, and hence for n > 3 the electron transfer would be too slow to be revealed by the ESR spectrum of the pertinent radical anion. McConnell s calculations justified the experimen- tal data available at that time [9,10] which implied a complete delocalization of an unpaired electron throughout the framework of bibenzyl radical anion. However, the more reliable studies of Gerson and Martin [11] conclusively proved that the unpaired electron of this radical anion is localized on one phe- nyl moiety only;the frequency of the intramolecular transfer in this spebies is, therefore, lower than 106 cps. The ESR spectrum of N. CH2 c-C6Hi0-CH2N (t1O~ M) in HMPA at various temperatures. The radical an- ion is present as a free ion and undergoes intrarnoiecularelec- Iron transfer, the rate of which increases with tempcrature. The mass spectrum reveals the molecular ion rn/c = 224 (18%), und two intense peaks at rn/e of 141 (32%) and 142 (3 5%). Hence, the identity of this compound is also verified. The ESR spectrum of c-C6H11---CH2N in I-BIPA (~ 104M) is shown in fig. 2. Its analysis led to the coupling constant listed in table I and the computer simulated spectrum is displayed in the same figure be- low the experimental one. The ESR spectra arising from inter- and intramo- lecular exchange are virtually identical in the slow ex- change limit, provided the rate of exchange is the same in both systems. However, their shapes are great Iy different in thefast exchange limit. A clear illustra- tion of these principles was provided by our past work [14]. Hence, the approach developed in those studies [14 17] has been applied in the present wosk. : ~ 15 October 1974 (b) Fig. 2. The 3SR spectriarri oFc.C6111i CH21f in HMPA. (a) The reccrded spectrum; (b) the computer simulated spec- trum using the coupling constants listed in table 1 and 1/7 ~ = 0.25 G. In the presence of 2.5 X 10 2 M of the unreduced hydrocarbon the spectrum broadens as shown in fag. 3. Although us shape at 15 C is not entirely identical with that of N. 2 c-C6H10 CH2.N recorded at the same temperature, the resemblance is sufficiently closet to indicate that the rate of intramolecular transfer, N.CH2_c~C5H10~.~CH2.N t~N1CH2 c-C6H10 CH2.N, is about the same as that of the intermolecular trans- fer at 2.5 X 10 2 M concentration of the parent hydro- carbon. The rate of intermolecular transfer was deter- mined by computer simulation of the spectra using the procedure described previously [15 17] as well as the method developed by Norris [5]. In the slow ex- change lin-ut both approaches lead to identical results; the examples of computer simulated spectra are shown * It was impossible to exactly match the spectra resulting from the intra- and intermolecular exchange. It seems that the ccupling constants of the N.CH2 c-C5H10 CH2.W ra- dical ion arc, slightly different from those of the c-C6Hi 5 CH2.N radical ion. The agreement between the simulated and observed spectra implies that the spectrum computed for P = 0.5 G (see fig. 4) corresponds to that obtalned forthe intermolecular exchange at 15 C when the concentration of the parent molecule is 2.5 X 10 2 M (see fig. 3). TI-se bimolecular rate constant of the exchange is therefore 3.5 X 108 M 1 s1 at 15 C, whereas the analogous rate constant previously re- ported [15 l 7,21] for the exchange of n-BuN with n-butyl ~-ruaphthy1 is 4.9 X 108 M~ r at that temperature. The agreement is gratifying. The similarity of the ESR spectra recorded at 15 C for the intramolecular and intermolecular ex- change (see figs. 1 and 3) implies that the frequency of intramolecular electron transfer, N.CH2 c-C6H10 CH2.W * N.Cli2 c-C6H10~CH2.N 0. 71 - in HIMPA at 15 C is about 0.9 X 10 r . Thus value corresponds to slow exchange but is surprisingly high inviewof the magnitude of the distance separating 45 C~ Fig. 3. The ESR spectra of c-C6H;1 CH2N ( ~ 10~ M) in HMPA in the presence of 2.5 X 10_2 M of c-C6H11 CH2N at various temperatures. Note the similarity of the spectrum re- sulting from the intermolecular exchange at 15 C with that resulting from the intramolecular exchange at the same tem- perature shown intig. 1. the two naphthyl moieties when they are most favor- ably oriented for the transfer. The model shows that the naphthyl moieties oriented parallel with respect to each other are about 9 A apart in such a conforma- tion. Six CH2 groups separate the two naphthyl moieties in N.CH2 c-C6H10~CR2.W and N4CH2)6 bV radi- cal ions. However, the frequency of the intramolecu- lar electron transfer in the open chain radical is 4.4X ~ s~ at 15 C [17],i.e.fivetirnesgreater than in the rigid cyclohexane radical. Although the relative number of conformations in which the trans- fer is impossible is greater in the open chain species than in the rigid one, the benefit arising from its flex- ibility which allows for a closer approach of the naph- thyl groups, leads to a higher rate of exchange. Clear- 543 Volume 28, iiurtuber 4 c Hex CH~F F + c Hex CH2N exchange 67,5 5 A CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 October 1974 The financial support of these studies by the Nat- bruni Sciesice Foundation and by the Petroleum ReL search Fujid administered by the American Chemical Society is patefully acknowledged. Appendix In a rec ~nt communication [22] Atherton has drawn attention to the basic difference between the effect of irisa- and intermolecular electron transfer on the shape of the respective ESR spectra. In es- sence, for intermolecular transfer every unpaired elec- trort will sooner or later visit a different nuclear spin NCH2~~2~ Fig. 4. The computer simulated ESR spectra calculated for various states of intermolecular exchange using the procedure described irtrefL [5,61-Note the similarity of the computed spectrum for P 0.5 G with that recorded at 15 C for the in- L~ molecuLar exbhange arid shown in 8g. 3. ly the probability of transfor considerably increases with decreasing separation of the partners. Finally, a few words should be devoted to the ob- servations of Gerson and Martin [li] and of Weiss- man [15] who found the electron in 4,4-para-cyclo- phane racflcal ions virtually localized although the dis- tance separating the phenyl groups in this species is thorter than 9 A. Two factors may account for these results. Either the radical ions were in the form of ion pairs and the presence of counterions hindered the ex- change, or the low r polar-izability of the phenyl moi- ety, as compared with naphthyl, reduce-s the interac- tion so much that the rate of transfer is too slow to be observed. 544 Fig. 5. The computer simulated ESR spectrum for various rates of inimainolecular exchange using the procedurede scribed in refe. [14 1 7]. Note the similarity between thespec trum simulated forF= 0.8 G and that shown in fig-4 and sirnu lated for tire fnteimolecuiar exchange but for the sam value ofF. However, the structure is lost at higher rates of intemmno lecular exchange (see, e-g., ref. j 15]). Volume 28, nu~nber 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15October 1974 state from that in which it started. However, for intra- molecular transfer there arC some unpaired electrons which never visit a different nuclear spin state. This distinction greatiy affects the shape of an ESR spectrum provided that the unpaired electron is coupled to a few protons only and the degeneracy of some lines is large relative to the total number of spin states. The example ~ven in Atherton s paper thus- trates well such a situation. The ESR spectra com- posed of many lines of low degree of degeneracy are less affected by this difference in the mode of elec- tron transfer, provided the exchange is slot too rapid. For example, figs. 4 and 5 show the computer simu- lated spectra of c~C6FI11~CH2N radical broadened by intermolecular and intramolecular exchange, respec- tively. Both are identical at the rate of exchange F 0.8 G. In conclusion, the inter-molecularly and intramo- lecularly broadenedESR spectra are identical at a not too fast rate of exchange, provided the number of lines is large and their degeneracy relatively low. Finally, a few words should be devoted to the ob- servations of Gerson and Martin [li] and of Weiss- man [15] who found the electron in 4,4-para-cyclo- phane racflcal ions virtually localized although the dis- tance separating the phenyl groups in this species is thorter than 9 A. Two factors may account for these results. Either the radical ions were in the form of ion pairs and the presence of counterions hindered the ex- change, or the low r polar-izability of the phenyl moi- ety, as compared with naphthyl, reduce-s the interac- tion so much that the rate of transfer is too slow to be observed. 544 Fig. 5. head.ce:title: How far can electrons be transferred?

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry, SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry, Syracuse, New York 13210, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
The intramolecular electron transfer between two naphthyl moieties (N) of trans-1,4-bis-(α-naphthyl-methyl)-cyclohexane in HMPA was studied over a range of temperatures
. Although the inspection of the model indicates a separation by 9 Å between the naphthyl groups the frequency of transfer is 0.9 × 107 s−1 at 15°C.
